conversation.content: [stern] The chlorine gas cloud is moving this way and we've got, [urgently], maybe fifteen minutes before this entire area becomes, [loudly], a death trap so you need to evacuate immediately.
[frustrated] I can't just abandon three hundred animals to, [shaky voice], die from toxic exposure while I save myself.
[angry] Listen, I've been doing hazmat response for twelve years and when I say, [firmly], evacuate, it means people are going to, [very quietly], die if they don't move right now.
[desperate] Well, um, the primates are still in their night enclosures and, er, the reptile house ventilation system will, you know, pull those fumes straight into their habitat within minutes.
Your safety protocols should have included, [coldly], emergency animal evacuation procedures but right now my job is saving, [empathetically], human lives first.
[crying while speaking] These animals trust me to protect them and I've raised, [passionately], some of them from birth, watching them grow, [trembling], knowing they depend on me completely.

[conflicted] Look, I understand the attachment but the wind is shifting and if you're still here when, [anxiously], that cloud hits, your animals will watch you, [whispering], die trying to save them.
[bitter] Um, you know, I've already lost two endangered snow leopards to, well, budget cuts last year and I mean, [defeated], I can't lose anyone else, not like this.
[resigned] Fine, we've got emergency respirators in the truck but, [quickly], you get five minutes maximum.
[relieved] Well, um, thank you, I mean, I just need to, er, get the baby orangutan and seal the ventilation systems.
[commanding] I'm coming with you because if you pass out from exposure, [grimly], I'll need to drag you out myself while there's still, [pause], time to escape.
[grateful] The emergency shut-off valves are in the basement but the, [worried], generator failed last week so we'll be working in darkness with just, [nervously], flashlights to guide us through.
[determined] Well, um, I've got headlamps and, you know, portable oxygen but we're burning time here.
Er, the orangutan won't come to strangers so, um, I'll need to coax her out myself while you, [pleading], handle the ventilation systems, and well, [exhausted], pray we're fast enough.
[sharp] Two minutes in, two minutes out, no exceptions because that cloud is, [ominously], already turning the sky yellow and once it hits, [trailing off], we won't get a second chance.
[resolute] I know, um, the risks but these animals would, er, die for me too if they could, [emotionally], understand what that meant.
Then we move now because every second we argue is, [harshly], another second closer to that poison reaching us and, [quietly], making this whole discussion pointless.
[accepting] Um, you're right, I mean, let's go save who we can while, er, we still have the chance.
[softly] After this is over, we'll come back for the rest with proper, [reassuringly], equipment and a full hazmat team.
[hopeful] Just promise me we'll try everything possible to, [bravely], save them all, even if it seems impossible.
